content: {{knowledge objective |Identifiant=OIC-006-06-A |Item_parent=The organisation of clinical practice and the methods that make it possible to secure the patient pathway |Item_parent_short=The organisation of clinical practice and the methods which make it possible to secure the patient pathway |Rank=A |Title=Checklists: understanding the principles and objectives of checklists |Description=None |Rubric=Definition |Contributors=Virginie Migeot |Order=6}} The '''''check-list "patient safety in the operating theatre" helps to "make safe" the performance of a surgical operation, by reviewing the situation between professionals at "key moments" in the operation. As in aviation, it encourages the "sharing of information" by "cross-checking", in particular the identity of the patient, the type of operation and the surgical site, the equipment and the risks involved. Other checklists exist in the medical world for so-called "interventional" activities (endoscopy, interventional radiology, central venous catheters, chemotherapy, etc.). Figure 3 : Checklist for patient safety in the operating theatre - 2018 version Source HAS [[File:Item6 Fig3.png|centric|thumb|812x812px]]

question.title: What is the primary purpose of a check-list in the operating theatre?
question.description: A brief description of the question

option_a.title: To ensure patient comfort during the operation

option_b.title: To improve communication among healthcare professionals

option_c.title: To document patient treatment and medication

option_d.title: To review and verify the safety of the operation at key moments

correct_option.title: A
correct_option.description: A letter indicating the correct option
